note:
Hi, I'm Aaron Parecki,  co-founder of
IndieWebCamp.
I maintain oauth.net, write and consult about OAuth, and
am the editor of several W3C specifications. I help people learn about video production and livestreaming and dabble in product design.

I've been tracking my location since 2008 and I wrote 100 songs in 100 days.
I've spoken at conferences around the world about
owning your data,
OAuth,
quantified self,
and explained why R is a vowel. Read more.
name: Aaron Parecki

name: New Draft of OAuth for Browser-Based Apps (Draft -11)
summary: With the help of a few kind folks, we've made some updates to the OAuth 2.0 for Browser-Based Apps draft as discussed during the last IETF meeting in Philadelphia.

content.html:
Is installing a Unifi Door Access system for my front door overkill? Yes.

Do I want to do it anyway? Absolutely.
content.value: Is installing a Unifi Door Access system for my front door overkill? Yes.   Do I want to do it anyway? Absolutely.

content.html: Turns out if you buy someone an @AlaskaAir flight with your airline miles, it gets added to your own Alaska account, and then you get push notifications when their flight starts boarding and have a mild panic because you thought you were supposed to be at the airport
content.value: Turns out if you buy someone an @AlaskaAir flight with your airline miles, it gets added to your own Alaska account, and then you get push notifications when their flight starts boarding and have a mild panic because you thought you were supposed to be at the airport

content.html:
Just published a new version of OAuth 2.0 for Browser-Based Apps!

https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-oauth-browser-based-apps-11.html

If you have feelings about tokens in browsers, please feel free to chime in on the discussion! You can comment on the mailing list or open issues on the GitHub repo linked from the doc!
content.value: Just published a new version of OAuth 2.0 for Browser-Based Apps!   https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-oauth-browser-based-apps-11.html  If you have feelings about tokens in browsers, please feel free to chime in on the discussion! You can comment on the mailing list or open issues on the GitHub repo linked from the doc!
